commit_message:
We don't have to disable validations anymore for pre-deployed OC

Following the Depends-On patch, we don't have to pass the
--disable-validations flag anymore when we deploy the OC on pre-deployed
nodes.

The doc still keep the mention of the option for a specific usecase
since it does make sense, for the sake of making Operator's life easier.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/771960

Change-Id: I87be5bf25f4ff3f6bfc2ccb311c5f0c9dea5a9bc

subject: Avoid distro installing unused services
messages:
[{'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-01-25 20:51:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-01-28 21:41:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-06 19:05:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-02-09 03:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-12 13:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-02-14 03:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-14 11:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-14 11:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1 -Workflow

The same needs to be done for suse/centos.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-14 13:27:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I was applying an if it ain't broke... philosophy to centos/suse since I was trying to solve a problem with apt automatically starting unnecessary services.  I figured if I left centos/suse unchanged I could do no harm.  I will add in the variables and see how the gates respond."}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-14 13:56:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-16 09:52:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-17 22:17:55.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+2 by Jonathan Rosser <jonathan.rosser@rd.bbc.co.uk>
'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-17 22:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I think this is mixing up the "service" and "distro" packages so will install openstack component distro packages during a source based install'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-18 19:57:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I do not see where this change is impacting what packages are installed during a source installation.  Please help me understand where the issue is.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-19 09:55:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I do not see where this change is impacting what packages are
 > installed during a source installation.  Please help me understand
 > where the issue is.

In this patch the issue is probably a semantic one. We had to revert similar patches to cinder and neutron because all of the reviewers missed the distinction between cinder_service_distro_packages and cinder_volume_distro_packages (one example), one being for distro and the other being for source install packages.

As a result of this I would be in favour of establishing a stronger naming pattern for the variables, perhaps with "service" being the distinguishing term for distro installed openstack service components.

My -1 here is really cautionary as we should establish a consistent pattern for these variable names across our roles.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-19 10:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Ah ok thanks.  I see what the problem is now.  Looking back at the cinder change the source gate uses cinder_distro_packages and the distro gate uses cinder_service_distro_packages.  But both gates consume cinder_volume_distro_packages which would now include the cinder-volume package which must have been the conflict.  Interesting that it was not caught by the gate.  It does not appear that the same conflict exists here since none of the overlapping variables are being changed, but I understand the need for caution.

And I see now that os_neutron uses neutron_metadata_agent_distro_packages variable in both the source and distro installs.  So that change would have installed the neutron-metadata-agent distro package during the source install scenario.  Creating a conflict there as well.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-19 19:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28665, 'date': '2019-02-20 14:31:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Avoid distro installing unused services

When performing a distro_install avoid installing services where they
are not needed.  The services are started automatically and are
consuming resources.  Add additional variables to differentiate between
source and distro package installs.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/636162
Change-Id: I519db8218aeb07d8fca0de595a986e264be7f545

[{'created': '2021-01-26 07:09:13.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize get_ports with trunk extension

Use case: many trunk ports (300+) each with many subports.
Issue: get_ports takes much time.
Solution: apply trunk resource extend func for a full list of ports,
not for each port individually, thus avoiding a DB query for each
trunk port.

The approach will be extended for other resource extenders, like QoS,
and probably for other resources as well.
QoS: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/764454

Change-Id: Ic08e4049f6156c0700ca3c7aee251b6eb0eb97da
Closes-Bug: #1905268
(cherry picked from commit e007349d47812f2307e8951ed44f3c392089bb3b)
'}]
commit_message:
Optimize get_ports with trunk extension

Use case: many trunk ports (300+) each with many subports.
Issue: get_ports takes much time.
Solution: apply trunk resource extend func for a full list of ports,
not for each port individually, thus avoiding a DB query for each
trunk port.

The approach will be extended for other resource extenders, like QoS,
and probably for other resources as well.
QoS: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/764454

Change-Id: Ic08e4049f6156c0700ca3c7aee251b6eb0eb97da
Closes-Bug: #1905268
(cherry picked from commit e007349d47812f2307e8951ed44f3c392089bb3b)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-10-19 16:32:05.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent archiving of pci_devices records because of 'instance_uuid'

Currently in the archive_deleted_rows code, we will attempt to clean up
"residue" of deleted instance records by assuming any table with a
'instance_uuid' column represents data tied to an instance's lifecycle
and delete such records.

This behavior poses a problem in the case where an instance has a PCI
device allocated and someone deletes the instance. The 'instance_uuid'
column in the pci_devices table is used to track the allocation
association of a PCI with an instance. There is a small time window
during which the instance record has been deleted but the PCI device
has not yet been freed from a database record perspective as PCI
devices are freed during the _complete_deletion method in the compute
manager as part of the resource tracker update call.

Records in the pci_devices table are anyway not related to the
lifecycle of instances so they should not be considered residue to
clean up if an instance is deleted. This adds a condition to avoid
archiving pci_devices on the basis of an instance association.

Closes-Bug: #1899541

Change-Id: Ie62d3566230aa3e2786d129adbb2e3570b06e4c6
(cherry picked from commit 1c256cf774693e2395ae8fe4a7a2f416a7aeb03a)
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent archiving of pci_devices records because of 'instance_uuid'

Currently in the archive_deleted_rows code, we will attempt to clean up
"residue" of deleted instance records by assuming any table with a
'instance_uuid' column represents data tied to an instance's lifecycle
and delete such records.

This behavior poses a problem in the case where an instance has a PCI
device allocated and someone deletes the instance. The 'instance_uuid'
column in the pci_devices table is used to track the allocation
association of a PCI with an instance. There is a small time window
during which the instance record has been deleted but the PCI device
has not yet been freed from a database record perspective as PCI
devices are freed during the _complete_deletion method in the compute
manager as part of the resource tracker update call.

Records in the pci_devices table are anyway not related to the
lifecycle of instances so they should not be considered residue to
clean up if an instance is deleted. This adds a condition to avoid
archiving pci_devices on the basis of an instance association.

Closes-Bug: #1899541

Change-Id: Ie62d3566230aa3e2786d129adbb2e3570b06e4c6
(cherry picked from commit 1c256cf774693e2395ae8fe4a7a2f416a7aeb03a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-07 11:13:08.000000000', 'message': 'Use subqueryload() instead of joinedload() for (system_)metadata

Currently, when we "get" a single instance from the database and we
load metadata and system_metadata, we do so using a joinedload() which
does JOINs with the respective tables. Because of the one-to-many
relationship between an instance and (system_)metadata records, doing
the database query this way can result in a large number of additional
rows being returned unnecessarily and cause a large data transfer.

This is similar to the problem addressed by change
I0610fb16ccce2ee95c318589c8abcc30613a3fe9 which added separate queries
for (system_)metadata when we "get" multiple instances. We don't,
however, reuse the same code for this change because
_instances_fill_metadata converts the instance database object to a
dict, and some callers of _instance_get_by_uuid need to be able to
access an instance database object attached to the session (example:
instance_update_and_get_original).

By using subqueryload() [1], we can perform the additional queries for
(system_)metadata to solve the problem with a similar approach.

Closes-Bug: #1799298

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/loading_relationships.html#subquery-eager-loading

Change-Id: I5c071f70f669966e9807b38e99077c1cae5b4606
(cherry picked from commit e728fe668a6de886455f2dbaf655c8a151462c8c)
(cherry picked from commit e2dc0de478ed16c2a811cde4aaa52f756c758fb5)

By using subqueryload() [1], we can perform the additional queries for
(system_)metadata to solve the problem with a similar approach.

Closes-Bug: #1799298

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/loading_relationships.html#subquery-eager-loading

(cherry picked from commit e728fe668a6de886455f2dbaf655c8a151462c8c)

commit_message:
Use subqueryload() instead of joinedload() for (system_)metadata

Currently, when we "get" a single instance from the database and we
load metadata and system_metadata, we do so using a joinedload() which
does JOINs with the respective tables. Because of the one-to-many
relationship between an instance and (system_)metadata records, doing
the database query this way can result in a large number of additional
rows being returned unnecessarily and cause a large data transfer.

This is similar to the problem addressed by change
I0610fb16ccce2ee95c318589c8abcc30613a3fe9 which added separate queries
for (system_)metadata when we "get" multiple instances. We don't,
however, reuse the same code for this change because
_instances_fill_metadata converts the instance database object to a
dict, and some callers of _instance_get_by_uuid need to be able to
access an instance database object attached to the session (example:
instance_update_and_get_original).

By using subqueryload() [1], we can perform the additional queries for
(system_)metadata to solve the problem with a similar approach.

Closes-Bug: #1799298

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/loading_relationships.html#subquery-eager-loading

Change-Id: I5c071f70f669966e9807b38e99077c1cae5b4606
(cherry picked from commit e728fe668a6de886455f2dbaf655c8a151462c8c)
(cherry picked from commit 63d2e62c3a223f883ca810f4c66a2a236cf3d483)

commit_message:
Change how ovn mech driver checks if vlan transparency is supported

Previously ovn mech driver was supporting vlan transparency for all
types of networks.
But it's not that easy and for flat networks it doesn't work (at least
for now). So this patch changes the way how check_vlan_transparency()
method is implemented in ovn mech_driver.

Change-Id: Ie5357980f70e4853f320785258cbb6bb603cc104

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-10-07 16:09:44.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Only add a USB controller if it's necessary

Libvirt will add a USB controller by default on x86-64 hosts. This is
legacy behavior due to QEMU's historical behaviour of not providing a
way to disable them. However, a USB controller is both unnecessary and
in some cases (real-time) actively harmful if there are no guest devices
that rely on the USB bus.

The libvirt documentation suggests that there are a number of devices
that can use a USB bus: input devices, various types of disk device, hub
devices, USB serial ports, sound devices, and host passthrough and
redirected USB devices. Of these, nova supports only the first two. Add
a check for these devices and if present, add a controller, else disable
the controller.

Change-Id: I5b16d9ddc9cad56b367d1ad94abba95d675840b0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-10-08 09:11:49.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Only add a USB controller if it's necessary

way to disable them. However, a USB controller is both unnecessary and

that rely on the USB bus.

The libvirt documentation suggests that there are a number of devices
that can use a USB bus: input devices, various types of disk device, hub
devices, USB serial ports, sound devices, and host passthrough and
redirected USB devices. Of these, nova supports only the first two. Add
a check for these devices and if present, add a controller, else disable
the controller.

Change-Id: I5b16d9ddc9cad56b367d1ad94abba95d675840b0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-10-09 15:58:57.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Only add a USB controller if it's necessary

Libvirt will add a USB controller by default on x86-64 hosts. This is
legacy behavior due to QEMU's historical behaviour of not providing a
way to disable them. However, a USB controller is both unnecessary and
in some cases (real-time) actively harmful if there are no guest devices
that rely on the USB bus.

The libvirt documentation suggests that there are a number of devices
that can use a USB bus: input devices, various types of disk device, hub
devices, USB serial ports, sound devices, and host passthrough and
redirected USB devices. Of these, nova supports only the first two. Add
a check for these devices and if present, add a controller, else disable

Change-Id: I5b16d9ddc9cad56b367d1ad94abba95d675840b0

commit_message:
libvirt: Only add a USB controller if it's necessary

Libvirt will add a USB controller by default on x86-64 hosts. This is
legacy behavior due to QEMU's historical behaviour of not providing a
way to disable them. However, a USB controller is both unnecessary and
in some cases (real-time) actively harmful if there are no guest devices
that rely on the USB bus.

The libvirt documentation suggests that there are a number of devices
that can use a USB bus: input devices, various types of disk device, hub
devices, USB serial ports, sound devices, and host passthrough and
redirected USB devices. Of these, nova supports only the first two. Add
a check for these devices and if present, add a controller, else disable
the controller.

Change-Id: I5b16d9ddc9cad56b367d1ad94abba95d675840b0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
policy: Remove the deprecated 'placement' rule

The 'placement' rule pre-dates the granular policies introduced in the
Rocky release, back when placement was still part of nova. It's no
longer used anywhere and can/should be removed.

This commit also updates a policy test to use a registered policy,
instead of the `placement` rule we're removing here.  Otherwise, the
`authorize()` implementation will fail because the rule isn't officially
registered by placement.

Change-Id: I4b34c86a1991f954fc562b8e252fe9a178a08ad7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-22 13:33:33.000000000', 'message': 'Default to cinder v3 in cloud config

Change Ib4f918c01e2fc71eedf7e6c90ca1dc5ccf8ff688 removed the cinder v2
API keystone service and endpoints. However some applications fail to
detect the supported cinder API versions and still default to v2.
See for example how Gophercloud [1] selects which API version to use.

This changes the default cinder API to v3 in the generated cloud config.

[1] https://github.com/gophercloud/utils/blob/6f54843/openstack/clientconfig/requests.go#L902-L918

Change-Id: I3fb719c2b8c92d2aebb76698674ada6b69ad2c8f
'}]
commit_message:
Default to cinder v3 in cloud config

Change Ib4f918c01e2fc71eedf7e6c90ca1dc5ccf8ff688 removed the cinder v2
API keystone service and endpoints. However some applications fail to
detect the supported cinder API versions and still default to v2.
See for example how Gophercloud [1] selects which API version to use.

This changes the default cinder API to v3 in the generated cloud config.

[1] https://github.com/gophercloud/utils/blob/6f54843/openstack/clientconfig/requests.go#L902-L918

Change-Id: I3fb719c2b8c92d2aebb76698674ada6b69ad2c8f

commit_message:
Implement secure RBAC for inventories

This commit updates the policies for the inventories resource in
placement to support read-only roles.

This is part of a broader community effort to support read-only roles
and implement secure, consistent default policies.

Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I9add612f1533d0810cbfd0eadc358759e285ab6a

commit_message:
Implement secure RBAC for usage

This commit updates the policies for the usage resource in
placement to support read-only roles.

This is part of a broader community effort to support read-only roles
and implement secure, consistent default policies.

This commit also allows project readers to see project-specific usages,
resolve a long-standing policy TODO.

Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I80afaae965d3c5f862320ac11a7d05db2f6b6553

commit_message:
Implement secure RBAC for allocations

This commit updates the policies for the allocations resource in
placement to support read-only roles.

This is part of a broader community effort to support read-only roles
and implement secure, consistent default policies.

Change-Id: I1f47f1a96e32d3bc9526c14e5541af7992fd1f72

commit_message:
Change the CLI document for the extend-attached-volume

The extend documentation will need to be updated to indicate that a
volume that is attached to an instance can be extended if the driver has
the capability 'in-use-extend'.

Prior to microversion 3.42 the volume status must be available.
Starting with microversion 3.42, attached volumes with status in-use
may be able to be extended depending on policy and backend storage.

Change-Id: I4d0a439dd53fc7eaee38d0a32fe4e6f0ab4fbf9f
Closes-Bug: #1871759

commit_message:
policy: Suppress policy deprecation warnings

These are making our logs rather horrific. Hide them.

Change-Id: I2853c7bd7c0afdeeed89ef412fc8830f04381d7b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

[{'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-21 16:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-21 16:23:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-21 16:25:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

The problem with switching this now is there may be consumers of these events already that are expecting the ID.

I do think we would want to stay with using the ID. If a user or a UI needs to display this in an easier to read manner, then they can do a lookup of the type name. Volume types can also be renamed, so using the ID ensures the correct type is always referenced.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-21 16:29:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > The problem with switching this now is there may be consumers of
 > these events already that are expecting the ID.
 > 
 > I do think we would want to stay with using the ID. If a user or a
 > UI needs to display this in an easier to read manner, then they can
 > do a lookup of the type name. Volume types can also be renamed, so
 > using the ID ensures the correct type is always referenced.

So, do you propose to fix the API then?
This API method " https://cinder.service.ewcs.ch/v3/{volume_id}/volumes/detail" is returning the volume type name, and this is the trouble we are having. We decided to fix the event data creation, so we would not need to change the API for the reasons you posted.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-21 16:33:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> 
 > So, do you propose to fix the API then?
 > This API method " https://cinder.service.ewcs.ch/v3/{volume_id}/volumes/detail"
 > is returning the volume type name, and this is the trouble we are
 > having. We decided to fix the event data creation, so we would not
 > need to change the API for the reasons you posted.

Sorry, I don't think I'm following. You get the volume type name for a given ID with this call:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=show-volume-type-detail-detail#show-volume-type-detail'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-21 16:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> >
 > > So, do you propose to fix the API then?
 > > This API method " https://cinder.service.ewcs.ch/v3/{volume_id}/volumes/detail"
 > > is returning the volume type name, and this is the trouble we are
 > > having. We decided to fix the event data creation, so we would
 > not
 > > need to change the API for the reasons you posted.
 > 
 > Sorry, I don't think I'm following. You get the volume type name
 > for a given ID with this call:
 > 
 > https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=show-volume-type-detail-detail#show-volume-type-detail

Without this change here, this API call: curl -s -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN_ID" -X GET -H "Content-type: application/json"  https://<servername>/v3/ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc/volumes/detail


is returning this:
    {"volumes": [{"status": "in-use", "user_id": "b0177350cb474b69a188269c7096fe49", "attachments": [{"server_id": "1d35b8f6-d4a9-4670-846e-1b68aeabd883", "attachment_id": "7f9dc86b-1ba5-4fc2-a04c-c3b723d0eafe", "attached_at": "2019-06-11T16:33:52.000000", "host_name": "ewos1-com2-prod", "volume_id": "edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "device": "/dev/sdb", "id": "edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329"}], "links": [{"href": "http://<servername>/v3/ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc/volumes/edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "rel": "self"}, {"href": "http://<servername>/ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc/volumes/edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "rel": "bookmark"}], "availability_zone": "ch-zh1-az1", "bootable": "false", "encrypted": false, "created_at": "2019-06-11T16:33:29.000000", "description": "", "os-vol-tenant-attr:tenant_id": "ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc", "updated_at": "2019-06-11T16:33:52.000000", "volume_type": "v-ssd-std", "name": "test-rwe", "replication_status": null, "consistencygroup_id": null, "source_volid": null, "snapshot_id": null, "multiattach": false, "metadata": {}, "id": "edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "size": 100}]}

Do you see the "volume_type" there?

This generated a lot of confusion for us because the Ceilometer pollsters use that call to retrieve data, which is then persisted in Gnocchi. The problem is that, when Ceilometer process the events generated by Cinder, the volume_type attribute comes with an ID. I am just proposing here for the event to use the volume type name as the API that lists volumes does.

Did you understand what I mean now?'}, {'account_id': 26537, 'date': '2019-06-21 17:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-24 23:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-24 23:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Thanks for the review Rajat Dhasmana. I addressed your comments.

I have a question though. How do you see this situation? I am not sure if I have been clear, but there is an inconsistency between the "event API" that is generated inside Cinder, and the Cinder restful API. This PR here is inteded to use the same "standard" of the restful API in the event data. Do you think that this method is ok?

One other approach would be to change these APIs, and use "volume_type_id" and "volume_type_name" in both "APIs". However, this would require us removing the "volume_type" attribute, which would break backward compatibility. That is why we are proposing a minimalistic fix now.'}, {'account_id': 26537, 'date': '2019-06-25 00:06:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

 > sure if I have been clear, but there is an inconsistency between
 > the "event API" that is generated inside Cinder, and the Cinder
 > restful API. This PR here is inteded to use the same "standard" of
 > the restful API in the event data. Do you think that this method is
 > ok?
 > 
 > One other approach would be to change these APIs, and use
 > "volume_type_id" and "volume_type_name" in both "APIs". However,
 > this would require us removing the "volume_type" attribute, which
 > would break backward compatibility. That is why we are proposing a
 > minimalistic fix now.

Sure, look at this request:
curl -s -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN_ID" -X GET -H "Content-type: application/json"  https://<servername>/v3/ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc/volumes/detail


is returning this:
    {"volumes": [{"status": "in-use", "user_id": "b0177350cb474b69a188269c7096fe49", "attachments": [{"server_id": "1d35b8f6-d4a9-4670-846e-1b68aeabd883", "attachment_id": "7f9dc86b-1ba5-4fc2-a04c-c3b723d0eafe", "attached_at": "2019-06-11T16:33:52.000000", "host_name": "ewos1-com2-prod", "volume_id": "edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "device": "/dev/sdb", "id": "edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329"}], "links": [{"href": "http://<servername>/v3/ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc/volumes/edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "rel": "self"}, {"href": "http://<servername>/ca6835d4c598410990262fa618527acc/volumes/edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "rel": "bookmark"}], "availability_zone": "ch-zh1-az1", "bootable": "false", "encrypted": false, "created_at": "2019-06-11T16:33:29.000000", "description": "", "os-vol-tenant-attr:tenant_id": "<tenant_id>", "updated_at": "2019-06-11T16:33:52.000000", "volume_type": "v-ssd-std", "name": "test-rwe", "replication_status": null, "consistencygroup_id": null, "source_volid": null, "snapshot_id": null, "multiattach": false, "metadata": {}, "id": "edc134c3-df0a-496d-bd40-2e8f0d00e329", "size": 100}]}

Do you see the "volume_type" there? It is coming with the volume type name. The problem is that the event generated by Cinder, which is then processed by Ceilometer uses the volume type ID. Do you understand what I am saying now?'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-25 11:02:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-25 11:11:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-25 11:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-06-25 11:49:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I get what you are saying Rafael, but this still is an issue that we can't just change what is being returned. This has been in place for a very long time now.

If we were to do this, we would need to add an API microversion that changes the return value when listing volumes to match. It should really be consistent in returning the ID anyway. And/or consuming code needs to be updated to handle the lookup of the ID to name to match things up."}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-06-25 11:53:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> I get what you are saying Rafael, but this still is an issue that

 > that changes the return value when listing volumes to match. It
 > should really be consistent in returning the ID anyway. And/or
 > consuming code needs to be updated to handle the lookup of the ID
 > to name to match things up.

That is great, it seems that we are on the same page. I have the same understanding as you. That is why we proposed to change the cinder event data, instead of the API. If we are changing the API to return both the id and the name, then we should return those in 2 separate fields instead of overloading 1 field.

I would much rather see
volume_type: <some name>
volume_type_id: <the id>

Other id related fields that we return are in the format of
name_id, such as
user_id,
snapshot_id,
group_id,
attachment_ids

We should do the same for this.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2020-04-29 14:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2020-04-29 14:13:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-06-16 13:28:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

Since this proposal has morphed from an event content change to a REST API change, it really needs a spec -- but, given that you have been working on this for a year and no one has mentioned that so far, I think we can let that slide.  Note to other people looking at this review: *This is a one-time exception that cannot be used as a precedent for other REST API changes*.

With that out of the way, my point is that you need to be very precise in the commit message and in the release note about what exactly this change does.  While the stuff about the event content was relevant to earlier patches, I don't think it is any more, and now it is confusing the issue.  (And I may be confused about what you are proposing, which is why I want to write it out.)

The use case is that in some contexts a consumer needs to know the ID of the volume_type.  For example, the volume-type-detail request requires the ID.  But the volume-detail response returns the volume-type name.  So to get the ID, you need to get the name from the volume-detail response, then make a list-volume-types request and search the response for the name so that you can find the ID, and then you can make the volume-type-detail request.  This is not very user friendly.

The proposal is to add a microversion so that the volume_type_id will show up in the volume-detail and volumes-list-detailed responses.  (You're not adding the volume_type name, that's already in the response, so you shouldn't mention it as part of your change.)

We need to be very clear about what you are trying to accomplish, or else it's impossible to tell if the code implements the correct change.  (For example, you code will also change the volume-show response for mv>=3.61, but you haven't included those changes in the api-ref or api-ref tests.)  So I'd like you to revise the commit message and release note to be clear about the above issues so that we can review your patch accurately."}, {'account_id': 24921, 'date': '2020-06-16 13:28:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-21 16:21:00.000000000', 'message': 'Cinder events fix for Volume type using volume type IDs instead of names

When the event (volume's events) data is created, Cinder is setting the volume type as the volume type ID. On the other hand, the pollsters are always updating the volume_type value in Gnocchi with the event type name. Then, for every volume event that is triggered in Cinder, this value is then updated back to the ID (it is like a "fight" between these two subsystems to see who updates the status last). The thing is that, deleted volumes are not polled. Therefore, the last update is executed by the event processing subsystems, which updates the value to the volume type ID. This explains why only deleted volumes were perceived with the volume type being set as the ID.

To fix this situation. We need to decide which "standard" we want to use. At first sight, it looks more natural (when integrating system-system via API) to use an ID, but for humans when accessing Cinder API, it might be better to see the volume type name instead. Because the API is publicly available, and we never know what consumes it, we believe that changing from volume type name to volume type ID can break things that we are not aware of. On the other hand, fixing the event data should not break anything because we know (hopefully) where that message is pushed to. Therefore, we decided to move on and fix the event creation code, and use the volume type name there.

Change-Id: Icb88faeb00040250a25a5630aeb312a8434ed3c8
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

Change-Id: Icb88faeb00040250a25a5630aeb312a8434ed3c8
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>
'}, {'created': '2019-07-01 12:01:41.000000000', 'message': 'Cinder fix for Volume type value in the API using name instead of ID

This change is a follow up on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666886.

=====================
A bit of context
=====================
When the event (volume's events) data is created, Cinder is setting the
 volume type as the volume type ID. On the other hand, the pollsters
 are always updating the volume_type value in Gnocchi with the event
 type name. Then, for every volume event that is triggered in Cinder,
 this value is updated back to the ID (it is like a "fight"
 between these two subsystems to see who updates the status last).
 The thing is that, deleted volumes are not polled. Therefore, the last
 update is executed by the event processing subsystems, which updates
 the value to the volume type ID. This explains why only deleted
 volumes were perceived with the volume type being set as the ID.

To fix this situation. We need to decide which "standard" we want to
 use. At first, we proposed to fix the Cinder event sub-system. However,
 after the discussions on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666886, the
 community suggested us to fix the Cinder rest API. Therefore, this
 PR is proposing the Cinder Rest API (volume API) to use the volume
 type ID, instead of the volume type name in the "volume_type" attribute.

Change-Id: Icb88faeb00040250a25a5630aeb312a8434ed3c8
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

=====================
A bit of context
=====================
When the event (volume's events) data is created, Cinder is setting the
 volume type as the volume type ID. On the other hand, the pollsters
 are always updating the volume_type value in Gnocchi with the event
 type name. Then, for every volume event that is triggered in Cinder,
 this value is updated back to the ID (it is like a "fight"
 between these two subsystems to see who updates the status last).

=====================
The fix
=====================
To fix this situation. We need to decide which "standard" we want to
 use. At first, we proposed to fix the Cinder event sub-system. However,
 after the discussions on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666886/6/, the
 community suggested us to fix the Cinder rest API. Therefore, this
 PR is proposing the Cinder Rest API (volume API) to use the volume

'}, {'created': '2019-07-03 14:18:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add microversion to return volume name and ID

When a volume events is created, Cinder is setting the
volume type as the volume type ID. On the other hand, the pollsters
are always updating the volume_type value in Gnocchi with the event
type name. Then, for every volume event that is triggered in Cinder,
this value is updated back to the ID (it is like a "fight"
between these two subsystems to see who updates the status last).
The thing is that, deleted volumes are not polled. Therefore, the last
update is executed by the event processing subsystems, which updates
the value to the volume type ID. This explains why only deleted
volumes were perceived with the volume type being set as the ID.

This adds a microversion to the API to return both the volume type name
and ID to provide both values depending on the consumer's needs.

Change-Id: Icb88faeb00040250a25a5630aeb312a8434ed3c8
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

'}, {'created': '2020-06-16 16:55:12.000000000', 'message': 'Introduces MV to add volume type ID in volumes details

Introduces microversion 3.61 to add volume type ID in the volume details.

This change comes to fix a problem we found in gnocchi concerning volumes
monitored data. When a volume event is created, Cinder uses the volume type
as the volume type ID. On the other hand, the Ceilometer pollsters are always
updating the volume_type value in Gnocchi with the volume type(which uses the
volume type name value) that is retrieved in the volume details.

That situation creates a massive number of resource revisions in Gnocchi.

commit_message:
Introduces MV to add volume type ID in volumes details

Introduces microversion (MV) 3.63 to add volume type ID
in the volume details.

This change comes to fix a problem we found in Gnocchi concerning
volumes monitored data. When a volume event is created, Cinder uses
the volume type as the volume type ID. On the other hand, Ceilometer
pollsters are always updating the volume_type value in Gnocchi with the
volume type from volume details API (which uses the volume type name
value).

That situation creates a massive number of resource revisions in
Gnocchi. This MV along with the Dynamic pollster system in Ceilometer
enables operators to overcome the issue.

Closes-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1911660

Change-Id: Icb88faeb00040250a25a5630aeb312a8434ed3c8
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

commit_message:
Update ACLs of Ironic Projects to allow Edit Hashtags

This patch aims to update the ACL for some of the Ironic
projecsts to allow the edit of hashtags

Projects updated:
- bifrost
- ironic-inspector
- ironic-specs
- ironic-ui
- ironic
- metalsmith
- networking-generic-switch
- sushy
- tenks
- virtualbmc

Change-Id: I736c807030cffff8d9017cbbbc8a252de902d423

commit_message:
Implement secure RBAC for aggregates

This commit updates the policies for the aggregates resource in
placement to support read-only roles.

This is part of a broader community effort to support read-only roles
and implement secure, consistent default policies.

Change-Id: I1242287418361ee48940f5bd2ee1bdc72cf1543e

commit_message:
Implement secure RBAC for resource providers

This commit updates the policies for the resource providers in placement to
support read-only roles.

This is part of a broader community effort to support read-only roles
and implement secure, consistent default policies.

This commit also introduces some testing infrastructure and plumbing
that is useful for implementing protection tests with gabbi. Including
testing for deprecated policies.

Change-Id: Icc904bf325eaa60377171a22a86932135c384e6a

Crikey. Good sleuthing.

I agree the right place to fix this is oslo.policy, but this is a good workaround that ought not break when/if op is improved.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-01-26 14:32:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I am not against of this change but we need to modify the note/cmt msg with it is best practice and can be fixed in oslo.policy to be more protective/safer if any future change (where oslo.policy start modifying the self.check_str) can cause the issue.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-01-27 21:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-01-28 12:49:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)

> I am not against of this change but we need to modify the note/cmt msg with it is best practice and can be fixed in oslo.policy to be more protective/safer if any future change (where oslo.policy start modifying the self.check_str) can cause the issue.



we can proably fix oslo.policy to make the copy of the rules internally yes

the other thing we can do in placement the current list_rules methods do the deep copy so that we never retrun pointers ot hte globals just a copy of them.

that however can be expensive at runtime where we dont expect rules to be modified.
this really is only an issue with tests'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-02-02 19:01:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(1 comment)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-26 12:24:34.000000000', 'message': "policy: Don't persist default rule changes in tests

'oslo.policy' expects a list of default rules be provided when
initialising the enforcer. Unfortunately, it demonstrates a nasty habit
of modifying these defaults once it has them [1]. This can result in
configuration from one test bleeding through to the next.

Resolve this by initialising the enforcer with a copy of the default
rules, rather than the originals, allowing 'oslo.policy' to do whatever
it likes to the rules. Ultimately this should probably be fixed in
'oslo.policy', which should be either copying the defaults or creating
new rules based on these defaults, but that needs some thought and can
be done later.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/3.6.0/oslo_policy/policy.py#L762-L764

Change-Id: Ib864606d4cf4a8ecba95386bcc2b8a4bb68f2d17
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Story: 2008556
Task: 41687

new rules based on these defaults, but that needs some thought and can

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/3.6.0/oslo_policy/policy.py#L762-L764

commit_message:
policy: Don't persist default rule changes in tests

'oslo.policy' expects a list of default rules be provided when
initialising the enforcer. Unfortunately, it demonstrates a nasty habit
of modifying these defaults once it has them [1]. This can result in
configuration from one test bleeding through to the next.

Resolve this by initialising the enforcer with a copy of the default
rules, rather than the originals, allowing 'oslo.policy' to do whatever
it likes to the rules. Ultimately this should probably be fixed in
'oslo.policy', which should be either copying the defaults or creating
new rules based on these defaults, but that needs some thought and can
be done later.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/3.6.0/oslo_policy/policy.py#L762-L764

commit_message:
Make it possible to override ServiceNetMap per-role

In spine-and-leaf TLS-e deployments as done in OSP13,
services are filter based on role networks when adding
metadata for nova-join. This filtering removes valid
services due to the fact that the roles network does'nt
match the global ServiceNetMap.

Add a role based parameter {{role.name}}ServiceNetMap
that can be used to override the ServiceNetMap per-role
when it's being passed to {{role.name}}ServiceChain and
the {{role.name}} resource group.

Related: RHBZ#1875508
Closes-Bug: #1904482
Change-Id: I56b6dfe8a0e95385e469d9eac97a0ec24e147450
(cherry picked from commit be6a844a79d659525e0feecd5a784e4eb55cb021)
